user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of calc_userhash:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
calc_userhash (struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
               const char *username, const size_t username_len,
               const char *realm, const size_t realm_len,
               uint8_t *digest_bin)
{
  mhd_assert (NULL != username);
  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
  digest_update (da, username, username_len);
  digest_update_with_colon (da);
  digest_update (da, realm, realm_len);
  digest_calc_hash (da, digest_bin);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No explicit compiler language extensions are present in the provided code fragment. The function signature and body use standard C constructs: parameter types (size_t, uint8_t) and the inline function style are standard. There are no visible GCC/Clang/MSVC extension tokens such as __attribute__, __asm__, __declspec, __builtin_*, typeof, __extension__, __inline__ (as a nonstandard spelling), inline assembly, or other vendor-specific keywords. The identifier _MHD_static_inline is a macro name in this snippet; its presence alone is not an explicit use of a compiler extension — the macro expansion (not shown) would need to be inspected to determine whether it expands to a compiler-specific extension. Similarly, other identifiers (mhd_assert, digest_update, etc.) are plain identifiers and not language extensions. For these reasons there are no code fragments in the provided snippet that explicitly use documented compiler language extensions and therefore nothing to report for Rule 1.2 based on the given code alone.
